The genius of #Scala's "Red Book" is that it explains very generic and hard to understand concepts in simple and very elegant code. And how many #Haskell books have you seen implementing their own `IO`?

It's not the code that library authors write, but gosh, it's the code we want to write. And #Scala is such a good language for learning #FP ❤️

If you want to learn functional programming, there aren't that many good books, and this is one of them...

title: Company Offers to Sell Computers Back to San Benito Schools

last_post.content:
Good grief...

San Benito school district (you may recognize the name from the recent disclosure of the #ransomware incident involving #Karakurt) sold thousands of district computers and devices at an online auction in July.

An auction company bought about 700 computers and it wasn't long before they discovered school district data -- employee data and student data -- on at least 11 of the hard drives.

So they contacted the district who tried to buy the computers back. The district doesn't want to pay what the buyer is asking and the buyer also refuses to sign a nondisclosure agreement.

Other than that, everything's just hunkydory....

Read more at GovTech, while @douglevin updates the k12six map with this one....

https://www.govtech.com/education/k-12/company-offers-to-sell-computers-back-to-san-benito-schools

title: Literature review on the benefits of static types

last_post.content:
I think this is unsurprising for a couple of independent reasons. One is, the base rate of sweeping claims that are proven "by studies" being borne out by the actual studies is quite low, e.g., https://danluu.com/empirical-pl/, https://danluu.com/dunning-kruger/, etc.

Maybe a stronger reason is that the claim is just highly implausible. There is, of course, high variance between different individual experts, so maybe lots of experts make bad predictions, but that doesn't mean no experts are credible.

title: Google Fi hack victim had Coinbase, 2FA app hijacked by hackers

last_post.content:
A Google Fi user got hit by a sim swap attack that resulted in his Authy account getting hacked. Since the hacker had control of the user's phone number, the hacker was able to add a new device to the Authy account and from there take control of the user's Coinbase and Outlook accounts.

One way to prevent this from happening to you is to make sure you (1) enroll at least one other device in your Authy account and then (2) have your Authy account set to disable multi device (as shown in the image below).

Doing task 1 will ensure that you always have at least 2 devices enrolled (in case you lose 1 of them). Task 2 will ensure that someone who gains control of your phone number won't be able to enroll new devices.

Solid reporting by @lorenzofb, btw.

https://techcrunch.com/2023/02/01/google-fi-hack-victim-had-coinbase-2fa-app-hijacked-by-hackers/

last_post.content: Bait is a bizarre but fascinating 2019 experimental British film about the tensions between a local fisherman whose trade is declining and the tourists visiting his town. "One of the defining British films of the decade" according to Mark Kermode (https://www.theguardian.com/film/2019/sep/01/bait-review-mark-jenkin-cornish-fishing-village)

title: Migrating Male Birds Race Ahead to Keep Up with Spring’s Early Arrival

last_post.content:
#Climate #change-driven earlier springs mean #migrating #birds return to their breeding ranges earlier. But #male birds from a number of species are arriving earlier and earlier than #females.

This could mean that arrival feeding, #reproduction, and foraging for food for the young also end up out-of-sync.

Climate change effects are everywhere, and even seemingly small but consistent temperature shifts can be amplified in #complex #ecological #systems.

title: Anti-intellectualism amid the COVID-19 pandemic: The discursive elements and sources of anti-Fauci tweets - Yingying Chen, Jacob Long, Jungmi Jun, Sei-Hill Kim, Ali Zain, Colin Piacentine, 2023

last_post.content:
New paper: In an analysis of 7960 tweets attacking #AnthonyFauci, Chen et al identify 3 themes:

1️⃣ 23% of tweets: people-scientist antagonism (conflict of “ordinary” people vs “elitist” science)
2️⃣ 40%: delegitimizing scientists’ motivation (scientists are allegedly corrupt)
3️⃣ 18%: delegitimizing scientists’ knowledge (evidence allegedly faulty)

Great to see #css methods applied to our concept of #science-related #populism @mss7676

I learned about this company last year from one of my students: https://www.causalens.com/

Their goal is to build #AI that can detect causal mechanisms in large datasets (ie move from correlation to causation).

On one hand, I want to say "this is absurd." Bc on one level that's all there is to it. On the other, it does raise interesting questions within & beyond political epistemology. Questions about meaning construction & narrative power especially interest me.
